quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 2 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 2.1: Relations vs. Functions
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Identifying functions, relations, and the Vertical Line Test

questions.question: Which of the following defines a function?
options: Every input corresponds to exactly one output.
Every output corresponds to exactly one input.
Every x-value has at least two y-values.
The graph passes the horizontal line test.
questions.explanation: By definition, a function is a rule that assigns each element in the domain to exactly one element in the range.

questions.question: Which set of ordered pairs represents a function?
questions.explanation: In set A, every x-value (1, 3, 5) is unique. In the others, at least one x-value repeats with a different y-value.

questions.question: If a graph fails the Vertical Line Test, what does that tell you?
options: The relation is not a function.
The function is not linear.
The domain is all real numbers.
The graph has no y-intercept.
questions.explanation: If a vertical line touches the graph twice, it means one x-value has two different y-values, which violates the definition of a function.

questions.question: Is the equation $x^2 + y^2 = 9$ a function of $x$?
options: No, because it is a circle and fails the VLT.
Yes, because it is a common geometric shape.
No, because $x$ can never be negative.
Yes, because every $x$ has exactly one $y$.
questions.explanation: If you solve for $y$, you get $y = \pm \sqrt{9 - x^2}$. One $x$ produces two $y$ values, and the graph is a circle.

questions.question: In the mapping of a function, can two different inputs have the same output?
options: No, that would violate the definition of a function.
Only if the function is a straight line.
Only if the output is zero.
questions.explanation: Functions can be 'many-to-one.' As long as each input only goes to one specific output, it is a function.

questions.question: Which of these graphs represents a function?
options: A parabola opening upward.
A circle centered at the origin.
A vertical line.
A parabola opening to the right.
questions.explanation: A vertical line will only hit an upward-opening parabola once at any point. Circles and sideways parabolas fail the VLT.

questions.question: The set of all possible input values for a function is called the:
options: Domain
Range
Codomain
Relation
questions.explanation: The domain is the set of all 'x' values that can be legally plugged into the function.

questions.question: If $f(x) = 5$ for every value of $x$, is $f$ a function?
options: Yes, it is a constant function.
No, because the y-value repeats.
No, because it has no slope.
Yes, because it is a vertical line.
questions.explanation: This is a horizontal line. It passes the VLT because every $x$ has exactly one output (which happens to be 5).

questions.question: Which of the following describes a relation that is NOT a function?
options: A person's height mapped to their age.
A person's age mapped to their height.
A car's VIN number mapped to its owner.
A student's ID number mapped to their GPA.
questions.explanation: At one specific age (input), a person can only have one height (output). However, one specific height (e.g., 5'10") could correspond to many different ages, making 'B' the most likely to be a non-function if the mapping were reversed.

questions.question: The Vertical Line Test helps identify functions. What does the Horizontal Line Test identify?
options: If a function is one-to-one (has an inverse).
If a function is linear.
If the function has a y-intercept.
If the domain is restricted.
questions.explanation: We will learn this later in Unit 2: if a function passes the Horizontal Line Test, it is one-to-one and has an inverse function.

scoreMessages.90: Great start to Unit 2! You've got the definitions down.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember: x cannot repeat, but y can.
scoreMessages.50: Review the Vertical Line Test and the definition of a function.
scoreMessages.0: Make sure you understand the difference between an input and an output.
